questions.text: 1. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Severe cases of alcohol withdrawal can be treated with I.V Flumazenil
Chronic opioid withdrawal can be treated with long acting drugs like Buprenorphine
Cannabis withdrawal is associated with minimal physical symptoms

questions.solution:
Severe cases of alcohol withdrawal can be treated with I.V Flumazenil is the false statement. 

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms include autonomic hyperactivity, such as anxiety, arousal, sweating, facial flushing, mydriasis, tachycardia, and mild hypertension. The classic sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness, commonly called the "shakes" or the "jitters". It also causes psychotic and perceptual symptoms (e.g., delusions and hallucinations), seizures, and delirium tremens. 

These are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as oxazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, and lorazepam. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and is not used to treat alcohol withdrawal. It is used to reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and in emergency care of benzodiazepine overdosage

Other options: 

Option B: Opioid withdrawal can cause symptoms like drug craving, feeling of temperature change, musculoskeletal pain, and GI distress. Signs of opioid withdrawal include confusion, drowsiness, vomiting, and diarrhea. It is not typically life-threatening, especially compared to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, which can lead to seizures or delirium tremens. Hence, opioid withdrawal is rarely fatal. 

Option C: Chronic opioid withdrawal can be effectively managed using long-acting opioids like buprenorphine or methadone. These medications help reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings and are a cornerstone of opioid substitution therapy.

Option D: Cannabis withdrawal is associated with minimal physical symptoms. The most common features include irritability, cannabis cravings, nervousness, anxiety, restlessness, insomnia, disturbed or vivid dreaming, decreased appetite, weight loss, depressed mood, and tremors.

questions.text: 2. "Lord hanuman is celibate. I am celibate. So, I am Lord Hanuman." What is this type of thinking seen in Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
This type of thinking as described is autistic thinking which is seen in Schizophrenia. 

Autistic thinking is defined as thinking in which the thoughts are largely narcissistic and egocentric, with emphasis on subjectivity rather than objectivity, and without regard for reality. It is seen in schizophrenia and autistic disorder. The reasoning "Lord hanuman is celibate. I am celibate. So, I am Lord Hanuman" is an illogical personal association not grounded in rational logic, characteristic of autistic thinking in schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Loosening of association is defined as gradual or sudden deviation in train of thought without blocking, also known as derailment. 

Option B: Neologism refers to new word or phrase whose derivation cannot be understood and is often seen in schizophrenia.

Option D: Verbigeration refers to meaningless and stereotyped repetition of words or phrases, also seen in schizophrenia.

Pearl PM2383: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas: Continuous flow of rapid, pressured speech that jumps from topic to topic. 

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking: Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantiality: Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations: An association of thoughts with the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming)

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration: Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking: A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."


DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality: In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment: A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms: The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts: Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad: Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"


DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion: Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal: Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting: Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo: Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 


 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions: Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions: Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobia: Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations: Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness: Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges: Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions: False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)


 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: 3. Which is the new psychoactive drug which has a rapid onset of anti-depressant action?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the new psychoactive drug which has a rapid onset of anti-depressant action. 

Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent which has been shown to produce a rapid, substantial, and persistent reduction in symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder. It inhibits the postsynaptic glutamate binding protein N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. Because abnormalities in glutamatergic signaling have been implicated in major depressive disorder, this may account for its efficacy.

Patients usually receive a single infusion of ketamine over a 30-minute period at a concentration of 0.5 mg/kg. A positive response is usually seen within 24 hours, and improved mood lasts for about 2 to 7 days.  Side effects like dizziness, headache, and poor coordination are commonly seen. Dissociative symptoms, including hallucinations, may also occur

Although ketamine appears effective, its use in depression treatment is off-label. Only esketamine, its S-enantiomer, is FDA-approved for major depressive disorder. 

Other options: 

Option A: Bupropion is an antidepressant that acts by dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. The onset of its therapeutic effect usually occurs during the second week of therapy. and is not known for rapid action. It is mainly indicated for smoking cessation. 

Option B: Mephedrone is a recreational psychoactive drug which has no proven antidepressant effects. 

Option C: Cannabidiol is a non-psychoactive compound from cannabis with potential therapeutic uses. However, its benefits are still being studied, and it is not approved for depression.

questions.text:
4. Which of the following drugs can be used in Acute Mania?

1. Lithium 2. Valproate 3. Haloperidol 4. Amitryptilline
questions.solution:
Lithium, valproate and haloperidol (1, 2 and 3) can be used in Acute Mania.

The pharmacological treatment of bipolar disorders is divided into both acute and maintenance phases. 

Treatment of acute mania includes: 

* Lithium: It is considered the prototypical mood stabilizer. But due to the slow onset of antimanic action with lithium, it usually is supplemented in the early phases of treatment by atypical antipsychotics, mood-stabilizing anticonvulsants, or high-potency benzodiazepines. Major drawback is its narrow therapeutic index (recommended plasma level 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L).

* Valproate: It is only indicated for acute mania at dose levels of 750 to 2,500 mg per day. It is well tolerated and associated with a rapid onset of response. 

* Carbamazepine and Oxcarbazepine: They are one of the first-line treatment for acute mania.

* Clonazepam and Lorazepam. They are high-potency benzodiazepine anticonvulsants which are widely used for adjunctive treatment of acute manic agitation, insomnia, aggression, and dysphoria, and panic.

* Atypical and Typical Antipsychotics: Older agents like haloperidol and chlorpromazine can be used, but atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine have a lesser liability for excitatory postsynaptic potential and tardive dyskinesia. 

Lithium, carbamazepine, and valproic acid, alone or in combination, are the most widely used agents in the long-term treatment of patients with bipolar disorder. 

Amitryptilline (Option 4)is a tricyclic antidepressant and acts by blocking the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine neurotransmitters. It is used to treat major depressive disorder, and not acute mania.

questions.text: 5. All of the following are cardinal symptoms of depression as per ICD-10 except:

choices.text: Low mood most of day and at all times

questions.solution:
Lack of self-esteem and confidence is not a cardinal symptom of depression as per ICD-10. 

According to the ICD-10 Classification of Mental and Behavioural Disorders, a depressive episode is typically diagnosed when at least two of the following three cardinal symptoms are present:

* Depressed mood (persistent low mood) to a degree that is definitely abnormal for the individual, present for most of the day and almost every day, largely uninfluenced by circumstances, and sustained for at least 2 weeks (Option C)

* Loss of interest or pleasure in activities that are normally pleasurable (Option A)

* Decreased energy or increased fatiguability. (Option D)

In addition, one or more of the following symptoms should also be present to make up a minimum total of four symptoms:

* Loss of confidence or self-esteem

* Unreasonable self-reproach or excessive and inappropriate guilt

* Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide, or any suicidal behaviour

* Diminished ability to think or concentrate (e.g. indecisiveness or vacillation)

* Psychomotor changes (agitation or retardation, subjective or observed)

* Sleep disturbances of any kind

* Change in appetite (increased or decreased), often with weight change

Loss of confidence and self-esteem is considered an additional symptom of depression in ICD-10, not one of the cardinal symptoms (Option B).

Pearl PM0496: Signs and symptoms of depression

Mnemonic "SIGECAPS"

Sleep disorder (increased or decreased)

Interest deficit (anhedonia): loss of interest in previously pleasurable activities

Guilt (worthlessness, hopelessness, regret)

Energy deficit

Concentration deficit

Appetite disorder (increased or decreased)

Psychomotor retardation or agitation

Suicidal tendency
